John Cage's musical composition urlLink As slow as possible for organ added two notes on July 5. The notes are changed manually by an organist, and weights keep the notes depressed for their duration. The piece will end in 636 years, provided the project continues to be funded, provided there are willing organists for the greater part of the next millenium, and provided we don't urlLink nuke ourselves into oblivion before then. In the four bars taking place between 2481 and 2489, there will be a spectacular flurry of hemidemisemiquavers. For perspective, this piece is about five million times the length of a Mahler symphony, and about one hundred million times the length of a typical Beatles ditty.

My brother just started as a surgeon at Stanford. He had an ID card made, but the staff forgot to put "MD" after his name. No big deal , he thought. He's not one of those MDs that insists on rubbing his education in other peoples' faces. He goes to the OR to start a surgery where he is the attending physician. When he enters, the anesthesiologist looks him up and down and says, "Excuse me, we were masks in the OR." What a jackass, my brother thinks to himself. As though I've never been in an OR!! He puts on his mask. Then he waits for the anesthesiologist to put the patient under so that he can go to work. He waits. He waits. He waits. He waits. He waits. Long minutes pass. The anesthesiologist stands there idly, sighing. Finally the anesthesiologist asks him, "Are you the attending?" My brother answers, "Yes, this is my case." The anesthesiologist chides him in the same snotty voice, "Well, I was waiting for you." And my brother thinks to himself, I've been standing here for 10 minutes!

The other day, when I was running on the Embarcadero near the ferry building, a white dude in a rastafarian hat started making fun of me. For a good 20 or 30 seconds, he ran alongside me and started pestering me, saying things like, "Hey, where you running to? Are you in a hurry? Why are you in a rush? You gotta learn to chill out!" I expect he thought that I was a soul-less, controlling, minutiae-obsessed person. Why not enjoy the moment? he might have been wondering. Why not soak up the euphoria? Of course I'm guessing what he was thinking -- why would he choose to poke fun at a total stranger? What he didn't know is: That day, because I had run so much that week, the very first step I took that day was tiring. But instead of stopping, I ran 8 miles. The pain didn't stop, and I didn't either. Every step was release from emotional pain, towards physical pain. Joy was absent; my only satisfaction was that I encountered the physical manifestation of pain, and instead of shrinking from it, I sought it out more. Use a razor blade to make the cuts you want to make, and you are labelled an emotionally unstable freak. Go for a punishing run on a cold, windy day, when the steps you take are excruciating, and you are hailed as "hard-core" (at least by some -- clearly the guy in the big rastafarian hat wouldn't have thought so), even though they bring identical release and sense of control in an otherwise reeling inner world. Is it cheating to pursue a socially acceptable form of masochism? Again, I think of the statement, You can feel like a mental patient, but that doesn't mean you have to act like one . In this case, I feel like one and I act like one. But others don't see the secret meaning of my actions, and somehow, that makes it OK. Even "healthy." Why?

I've been listening to an arresting CD called urlLink Hamdullilah, a collection of religious songs from all over the world. The urlLink narcissist lent it to me. Taqtouqa Al Iabaliyya is what arrested me. He sings no emasculated, angelic praise to God. No: he reverberates from his viscera to his sinuous throat-strings. He sings in this instant, in this world of flawed bodies, of fruit-bearing landscapes and famines, of loves supreme and mortal enemies. This world at this time, this double conviction which is our only given. His singing, intended to praise the transcendent, instead celebrates the corporeal present. To this I say, yes, yes, yes! But with God comes the false hope that our lives have purpose -- purpose, which robs us of our magnificent autonomy, and which seeks to wrench us from our only given. So I reject God while I greedily devour every drop of the blood that He draws from believers. This is my desire for belief.

Philosophers of the mind and logicians assert that even with great empathy and imagination, as a matter of principle we can never fully understand another person's thoughts. We cannot shoulder another's pain, much as we would like to, nor can we share in another's ecstasy. Our lives are ours, and ours alone, to bear. But sometimes, we play music with others, or we dance a pas de deux, or we pass a baton in a race. The most exquisite moment of all chamber music is the breath that we take on the upbeat before the first measure. Suddenly, out of necessity, we are our fellow musicians because they are also us. For a quarter measure, before we sound the first notes, the walls that keep us from each other are made permeable. Rilke writes, Who knows? perhaps the same bird echoed through both of us yesterday, separate, in the evening. Can this quarter measure be domesticated? We see the same stars. We crave the same sensations.

urlLink This article looks a bit dodgy, seeing that it's for selling something, but it is interesting nonetheless: Eating a high protein diet to provide more tryptophan only worsens the problem by even more increasing the intake of the 5 competing amino acids. Ironically, the only dietary strategy that increases brain tryptophan supply is to eat a high carbohydrate diet. When large amounts of carbohydrates are eaten, the body secretes large amounts of the hormone insulin to lower the ensuing high blood sugar. The insulin also clears from the blood most of the 5 amino acids that compete with tryptophan for a ride to the brain. Tryptophan then has the "bus" all to itself, allowing more tryptophan to reach the brain. This strategy is instinctively known and practiced by many people who eat large amounts of carbohydrates like bread, cakes, pies, ice cream, chips, pizza, candy etc., especially when they are feeling depressed, stressed or anxious. OK, from now on it's Thanksgiving every day for me!!!

urlLink This article points out that different diets have different entropy to free energy ratios depending on the metabolic paths required, and that certain diets - particularly low-carb diets - may be particularly metabolically inefficient and therefore weight-loss inducing (emphasis on the word "may"). Thus, ironically the dictum that a "calorie is a calorie" violates the second law of thermodynamics, as a matter of principle. Well-stated! Research described urlLink here seeks to address the effects of the amino acid tryptophan on major depression. It appears that even in remission, depressives show different responses to stimuli than people who are not depressive. Two bottom lines: 1. "Since brain function appears to be disregulated even when patients are in remission, they need to continue long-term treatment beyond the symptomatic phase of their illness," says Neumeister. 2. People with a history of depression are more likely to experience fleeting symptoms and brain overactivity when sapped of [tryptophan]. So make sure you get enough tryptophan, especially if you have a history of depression!
